thread.title: Donald Trump in nuclear-powered 'show of force' against North Korea
thread.title_full: Donald Trump in nuclear-powered 'show of force' against North Korea

title: Donald Trump in nuclear-powered 'show of force' against North Korea
text:
Published 1st February 2017 
GETTY WARPATH: Donald Trump, Kim Jong-un, and the USS John C Stennis, which may join the exercises 
The new president is reportedly considering the action as he tries to position himself as tough on America's enemies. 
While a senior foreign policy chief in his party has suggested a pre-emptive strike may be necessary to end Kim's missile threat. 
It's all in response to the North Korea's planned launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile (ICBM) with the potential range to strike America. 
GETTY PALS: Donald Trump with Bob Corker at a Rally in Raleigh, North Carolina “Should we consider an approach that proactively pursues regime change in North Korea?” US Senator Bob Corker 
A source in the South Korean government said the deployment, which could also see bombers deployed, would be finalised in February after "comprehensive review". 
They said: "US military authorities are considering deploying strategic assets on the Korean Peninsula in preparation for a provocation by North Korea including a test launch." 
Republican US senator, Bob Corker, who chairs the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, urged Washington to "think outside the box" when dealing with Pyongyang. 
One option, he told the committee on Tuesday, was to “to preemptively strike a North Korean ICBM" before Kim Jong-un could successfully finish testing it. Inside North Korea: The pictures Kim Jong-un doesn't want you to see Tuesday, 13th December 2016 Since 2008, photographer Eric Lafforgue ventured to North Korea six times. Thanks to digital memory cards, he was able to save photos that was forbidden to take inside the segregated state 1 / 62 Eric Lafforgue/Exclusivepix Medi Taking pictures in the DMZ is easy, but if you come too close to the soldiers, they stop you 
He continued: "Should the United States consider a policy approach that proactively pursues regime change in North Korea by non-kinetic means?” 
Kinetic military action is a euphemism for military action that involves lethal force, however, so no assassination mission seems likely. 
Trump gave an "ironclad" commitment to defend South Korea with he spoke with Hwang Kyo-ahn, acting South Korean president, on Monday. 
Defense Secretary James Mattis spoke with his South Korean counterpart Han Min-goo the following day and is due to visit today. 
Gen. Lee Sun-jin, chairman of South Korea’s Joint Chiefs of Staff, also talked over the phone with his US counterpart Gen. Joseph Dunford, yesterday. 
In a phone call lasting some 20 minutes, the duo agreed to form a “strong joint defense posture” against North Korean provocations. Related articles
